title: Are there any White groups in the Bible other than the Romans? - Quora

response.answer_text: Every fiber of my being is screaming at me not even to address this question. But because I apparently lack any sense, I’m forging ahead anyway. By “white” I assume you are referring to people of European ancestry, not merely the color of one’s skin. That being the case, in the New Testament at least, there are several groups of European origin that are mentioned in the Bible. To start, Paul addresses many of his letters to churches that he established in modern day Greece. These include the communities he founded in Corinth, Thessalonica, and Philippi. As you may imagine, the population here was probably mostly ethnically Greek. Other churches established by Paul were founded on the west coast of modern day Turkey, most notably his church in Ephesus. While we might think of these residents as something other than “white” in modern times, owing to the invasion of this area by the Ottoman Empire, during the first century this region had been settled by Greeks. Although, the question of ethnic identity becomes complicated here (as it is pretty much everywhere) because this region had traded hands between the Greeks and the Persian Empire centuries before. So there was probably a lot of genetic integration from these exchanges. In the central region of modern day turkey, Paul established the churches of Galatia, which had been settled by ethnic Celts and then conquered by Rome. So if you consider the Celtic tribes to be “white,” then you may want to include this group as well. Outside of Paul, the book of Revelation includes seven letters to seven churches in its opening chapters. These are churches in Ephesus, Smyrna, Pergamum, Thyatira, Sardis, Philadelphia, and Laodicea. All of these sit on the western region of modern day Turkey, and so perhaps the same ethnic description that I provided for Ephesus above applies to all of these areas as well. The first letter attributed to the apostle Peter (1 Peter) is addressed to the following regions: Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, Asia, and Bithynia. With the exception of Asia, which is a complicated reference, the other four regions all refer to areas of northern modern day Turkey. So the ethnic description of the Galatian inhabitants as Celts referenced above would probably apply here as well. As a huge caveat to everything mentioned above, bear in mind that all of these regions were under the reign of the Roman Empire during this time. As with most regions of the Empire, there was a lot of trade between regions, and much travel among some certain groups of people (e.g., slaves and their descendants who were forcibly displaced from their homelands). Much of the empire was fairly metropolitan and consisted of a variety of ethnic groups. So there is a very real sense in which talking about ethnic identity at all is a problematic exercise at best, and perhaps even futile. There is also the question of utility here. What do we gain from identifying various groups mentioned in the Bible as “white” or “non-white”? I would suggest to you that these two categories are a relatively modern phenomenon, and is emblematic of concerns that we have today in issues pertaining to race and ethnicity. This is very likely not a question that would have been asked in the ancient Mediterranean environment in which the New Testament was written.

Yes everyone in the Bible believed themselves to be white, just about. In Numbers 12: 1, Moses is recorded as having given offence because of his marriage to someone from Southern Sudan or the Horn of Africa: “Miriam and Aaron spoke against Moses because of the Cushite woman whom he had married, for he had married a Cushite woman.” So there is apparently one Black person in the Bible, Mrs Moses, but it follows that Moses himself was not of this hue. Jeremiah 13:23 says: “Can the Ethiopian change his skin or the leopard his spots?” Black skins are thus a characteristic of Ethiopians, not Jews. Syrians are not by any measure Black, and are known to be the fairest of Arabic speaking people, apart from Circassians. All Mediterranean people, Spaniards, Italians, Greeks and Syrians were much of a muchness, and still are. The Romans remarked that the Celts were fair, and the Germanii even fairer. They said nothing about the Jews being of a different hue. The problem arises when you attempt to impose American categories onto the Ancient Middle East.

It’s probably worth noting that with the Romans originating from the Italian peninsula, they were probably just as dark-skinned as many of the Aramaic people. Heck, I had family migrate from Italy about 100 years ago, and when they first came to the U.S., they weren't even considered “white”. That being said, what is so “evil” about the Romans? They were an empire that conquered. That was a pretty standard practice back then, and not really anything that was inherently “evil”. Yes, the Romans had conquered Judea, but as was their standard practice, they would usually let the subjugated peoples rule themselves and handle their own internal affairs. I do believe the Roman governor Pontius Pilate himself did not want to crucify Jesus, but caved into the demands of the local Jewish rulers because he was on the receiving end of a lot of flak from the emperor due to some previous rebellions that had gotten out of hand.

The Roman Empire covered a large area so Roman citizens came in many skin colors, not just white. And the Ancient Romans were not necessary evil. Their time period was a very violent, harsh, brutal time period. All people groups at that time owned slaves and decimated enemies. Its just the way that time period was. By the standards of their time the Romans were actually very liberal and enlightened and sophisticated and accepting. As long as people obeyed laws and didnt commit violence the Romans didnt care what they did. And, no, in that time there were no large people groups who werent violent and brutal toward their enemies. Even the Jews were quite brutal toward non-Jews in many cases.

Romans are evil? Paul was both Jew and a Roman. Peter was a Galilean Greek. Paul, by most accounts, did his best writing in his letter to the Romans. It took a while, but the entire Roman Empire converted to Christianity, which became the official religion. Honestly, do you need to bring race into a discussion of a religion that is explicitly open to every human being?

Some Romans were black, and the Romans as such are not depicted as “evil”. Keep in mind that relatively few “Romans” were actually born in Rome, and Rome was a highly cosmopolitan empire. Having said that, other than the Greeks, I am not aware of any groups besides Roman nationals mentioned in the Bible who would be called “white” today. Modern Jews occasionally get lumped into whatever “white” means—which isn’t much—but I have no idea how indicative modern skin tones are of ancient ones.

If you look at the evolutionary morphology of color, you see environment having the majority to do with the changes….assuming the theories are correct, all of mankind came out of Africa, and all started out as black, so from that point of view yes… but in reality looking at the different define cultures of today, skin color for Jesus would have been brown; but not much more… As for Christ, according to the experts, he had no more African american blood, than the average Englishman…. Yet the arguments continue……..

Greeks. Hittites, perhaps. Philistines were part of the Hellenic sea-peoples. Persians are part of the Indo-Aryan language group, as Latin, Greek, English. Are there nordic “Aryan” blue eye blondes? Not that I can imagine. But since there are now, there must have been then too. Noah went into the Ark with his wife and three sons. Presumably the sons are from the same mother. So they must have resembled each other. The variation in human “races” must have been in their wives. Therefore the sons of Japheth who are said to include among their descendants Greeks and Romans must have had caucasian-like features.

Humans come in one color : brown. Light brown, dark brown. Many shades of brown. No humans are white, black, yellow or red. I have a permanent tan on my forearms (from working construction) that is as dark as my “black” grandson’s skin. Beyond geography, race is an illusion. I take racism very seriously because it is a family thing.  This is my grandson. He is a badass Marine and don't you forget it. I could not be more proud of this young man.
